image.altText: The 250 metre-tall tower in the middle of Noor Energy solar plant.

props.synopsis: This solar thermal plant in the United Arab Emirates could harness enough of the Sun's rays to power a city the size of Brisbane for a year but being able to run one in Australia could prove difficult.

title.children: In the UAE desert, a shining beacon looms large. Experts say it could help Australia go green

image.altText: Illustration of 75 year old woman with walking stick and electric fans warm yellow and peach colour tones.

props.synopsis: Over the next few months, we'll endure heatwaves in different parts of the country. Extreme heat can be life-threatening for some people — and not necessarily the ones you expect.

title.children: How work, a cricket game and even just sitting at home can be catastrophic during a heatwave

image.altText: Two female children choose from a tin of coloured textas

props.synopsis: The review was carried out following allegations a former Gold Coast childcare worker allegedly abused 91 girls in Brisbane, Sydney and overseas.

title.children: Childcare workers to be banned from using personal phones at work after nationwide review into child safety

image.altText: a pile of gold bullion and coins

props.synopsis: It took seven years of expensive, drawn-out legal battles, but one of the oldest and biggest private precious metals companies in Australia closed a dark chapter in the gold refining industry with a recent win against the ATO, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Inside the gold scam that made a fortune — and cost taxpayers millions of dollars

image.altText: A JB Hi-FI sign outside a shop with two people walking past.

props.synopsis: Is an extended warranty worth your money? It's a question being raised in a new class action against retail giant JB Hi-Fi.

title.children: Ever bought an extended warranty? A new lawsuit claims customers have been misled by a major retailer

image.altText: the premier speaking behind a lecturn

props.synopsis: It's a rare opportunity not granted to all political leaders to control their legacy and quit while on top — and leaving it too late was a risk Annastacia Palaszczuk wasn't going to take.

title.children: Annastacia Palaszczuk's resignation was a bombshell to many, including some of her closest colleagues

image.altText: a composite image with the headshots of steven miles, shannon fentiman and cameron dick

props.synopsis: Steven Miles has thrown his hat in the ring to succeed Annastacia Palaszczuk as Queensland premier – but he may still face a challenge in his bid to take up the state's top job.

title.children: Who will replace Annastacia Palaszczuk as Queensland premier?

image.altText: A middle-aged man stands in profile with a security on his left.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian MPs returning to parliament tomorrow to consider a move to suspend a judge facing criminal charges are told they may not have the necessary powers to do so.

title.children: Bid to suspend Tasmanian judge has potential to end up in High Court, MPs told

image.altText: Milei standing at a podium speaking into microphones holding up a fist

props.synopsis: Argentinian President Javier Milei takes office, warning of dark times as he attempts to guide the nation out of its worst economic crisis in decades, with inflation heading towards 200 per cent.

title.children: 'Debt bombs' and 'no money': Argentina President Javier Milei delivers bleak inauguration speech

image.altText: Man walks barefoot on rubble and debris of his home.

props.synopsis: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says dozens of Hamas militants have surrendered, but Hamas has called the claim "false and baseless".

title.children: Hamas denies dozens of militants have surrendered to Israeli military

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Jordan says Israel aims to expel Palestinians from Gaza
Israeli military's push into Gaza's south has taken 'longer than they thought'
'Gunshots and explosions that didn't stop for hours': Ongoing bombardment in Khan Younis

image.altText: A crowd of people, some waving flags, lined up under a big red marquee

props.synopsis: In an election viewed by critics as a sham, Abdel Fattah al-Sisi is pegged to win a third term as the president of Egypt, which is grappling with an economic crisis.

title.children: Egyptians vote in presidential election expected to keep Sisi in power

image.altText: large ship labeled "china coast guard" blasts a smaller ship with strong stream of water

props.synopsis: A Philippine boat and a Chinese Coast Guard ship collide near a hotly contested reef, with both countries trading blame for the latest confrontation in the disputed South China Sea.

title.children: Philippine and Chinese vessels collide in disputed South China Sea

image.altText: Cyclone Jasper satellite image.

props.synopsis: North Queensland residents as far south as Mackay are being warned to brace for damaging winds as Cyclone Jasper continues to track toward the coast.

title.children: Cyclone Jasper warnings for damaging winds expanded further south to Mackay

image.altText: tree over a home after a strom

props.synopsis: More than 20,000 homes and businesses are currently without power and there have been 500 calls to the State Emergency Service (SES) for assistance over a weekend of wild weather in South Australia.

title.children: Thousands of homes and businesses without power after wild storm lashes SA

image.altText: A row of electric vehicles inside a storage area of a car company.

props.synopsis: With better supply and affordable options, second-hand electric vehicles are set to become more popular in Australia. Here's what you should know before getting one.

title.children: Australia's expected to see 'significant' growth in second-hand EV sales. Here's what to know before getting one

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith arrives at court

props.synopsis: Despite the war veteran's case ending just six months ago, streaming service Stan — which is owned by Nine Entertainment — fast-tracks a documentary on the case to the small screen.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith's landmark defamation case ended in June, now it's a documentary. Here's what we learnt

image.altText: The Charging Bull statue in New York's financial district

props.synopsis: Bad economic news has recently been pushing shares higher amid hopes it will accelerate rate cuts. But now good economic data is also sending stock markets up. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Good news now also buoying global markets as falling US unemployment drives shares higher

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Record migration keeping Australia out of one kind of recession, may push it into another: HSBC
ASX matches Wall Street with early gains
Traders bet on 'Sully'-style landing for US economy

image.altText: A crowd pulses through the city

props.synopsis: Minimum English language requirements for international students will be increased, and more restrictions will be applied to stop onshore "visa hopping" as the federal government sets its new migration strategy.

title.children: New migration strategy to clamp down on migrants living in Australia in a 'permanently temporary' state

image.altText: The University of New South Wales (UNSW) library is seen against a bright, cloudy sky

props.synopsis: UNSW has been conducting a "preliminary" investigation into research misconduct for more than two years. Now the university itself will be investigated.

title.children: UNSW to face review over research misconduct processes that have taken more than two years

image.altText: A man with a hard hat looks into the camera with controlled fire behind him.

props.synopsis: Four years after the devastating Black Summer bushfires, Indigenous fire practitioners say they're struggling to keep up with demand for cultural burns from private landholders, and they want more support.

title.children: Cultural burns are small, slow and controlled, and they're in high demand on private properties

image.altText: Culturally significant artefacts by William Barak at an exhibition

props.synopsis: Two works by Aboriginal artist and advocate William Barak will go on display this week after being returned to Victoria 126 years after they were gifted to a Swiss family.

title.children: More than a century after they were gifted to a Swiss family, William Barak's artworks have returned

image.altText: Perth Scorchers batter Josh Inglis speaks to Melbourne Renegades' Joe Clarke as they walk off the field at a Big Bash game.

props.synopsis: Hours of heavy rain in the Geelong area seem to have affected the pitch at Kardinia Park, prompting the BBL clash between the Melbourne Renegades and Perth Scorchers to be called off.

title.children: 'The wicket's absolutely drenched': Big Bash game called off due to unplayable pitch in Geelong

image.altText: a toddler in an orange shirt peers around a leg

props.synopsis: Following an era of pandemic restrictions and back-to-back natural disasters, many residents in and around Myrtleford were feeling isolated, but a weekly all-ages get-together is changing that.

title.children: Plenty of lessons to be learnt at this playgroup, where it doesn't matter if you're one or 101

image.altText: Man in workshirt looks at seedlings

props.synopsis: From pink custard apples and sweeter capsicums that resemble the colour of chocolate, these Queensland farmers are working to bring innovative new varieties to supermarket shelves.

title.children: Farmer startups backing themselves to bring chocolate capsicum and other 'new fruit' to markets

image.altText: Jimmy Spithill claps his hands following an America's Cup race in 2021.

props.synopsis: Stand-in Team Australia helmsman Jimmy Spithill bows out of SailGP racing after his Flying Roo finishes second in the global league's Dubai leg.

title.children: Aussie sailing great makes retirement call

image.altText: Lydia Ko and Jason Day celebrate with a trophy after winning a mixed teams event.

props.synopsis: Two of Australia and New Zealand's best combine to claim victory in the inaugural Grant Thornton Invitational in Florida, winning by one stroke.

title.children: Jason Day, Lydia Ko pair up to win mixed teams event in US

image.altText: two painted power poles beside a man sitting on a ute tray with a bushy beard and glasses

props.synopsis: In a beaten-up ute, David Rowe is a familiar sight in the Queensland town of Lucinda, where he splashes colour and humour onto roadside canvases one power pole at a time.

title.children: Over 20 years, not a single one of David's roadside artworks has been graffitied

image.altText: A portrait of a young girl outdoors, smiling into the camera. The background is of bushland, grass and woodchips on the ground.

props.synopsis: Watching water go to waste while waiting for the shower to get hot sparked an idea that high school student Rani East-Jeffs hopes can help save thousands of litres of the precious resource. It's also caught the attention of Australia's inventors.

title.children: Do you use a bucket in the shower to save water? This award-winning young inventor has found a better solution

image.altText: Ariarne smiles softly in a selfie of her lying in bed in her silk stripped pajamas.

props.synopsis: When Olympic swimmer Ariarne Titmus had to have surgery in September she was reluctant to go public but selfie requests from nurses led to her changing tack and now she wants to normalise conversations about women's health.

title.children: Ariarne Titmus intended to keep her surgery 'under wraps' but selfie requests from nurses changed that

image.altText: Prince William and Princess Kate post for a photo with their children George, Charlotte and Louis.

props.synopsis: No one does holiday cards quite like the royals with the Wales family and King and Queen sharing their chosen selections for 2023.

title.children: King Charles and Camilla, and Prince William and Kate, release new family photos for Christmas cards

image.altText: A man wearing a blue robe with yellow belt around the middle, and a cap on his head, stands in front of a shed

props.synopsis: Davaadorj and his family call the vast sand dunes of the Gobi Desert in Mongolia home and live off the land. But that delicate balance is shifting against them, as the terrain and the weather become even harsher and more volatile due to a rapidly changing climate.

title.children: Known as 'white death', a terrifying weather phenomenon is changing lives and unleashing horror in Mongolia
